newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's east Prairie crops need rain soon - CWB.
newsitem.headline: Canada's east Prairie crops need rain soon - CWB.

text.p: Crops growing on Canada's eastern Prairie need rain in the next week or yield potential may drop off, a Canadian Wheat Board weather analyst said.

"Generally, the western half of the Prairies has good soil moisture but the eastern half has been dry, especially south east Saskatchewan and southwest Manitoba are in the most critical stage," CWB weather analyst Bruce Burnett said.
Cereals grain there are in tillering, the stage that determines the number of shoots that grows out of the plant.
"So they're going to need rain in the next week or so or (yield) potentials will drop off," Burnett said.
All wheat seeded area on the Prairies was seen 9.2 percent down at 28.22 million acres in 1997 from 31.08 million acres the year before, Statistics Canada said April 30.
Average yield per bushel in all categories of wheat across the Prairies last year was 32.6 per acre, StatsCan said.
Canola area was forecast to rise 32 percent to 11.858 million acres from 8.8 million, StatsCan said.
Canola yield averaged 21.7 bu/ac last year, it said.
Thunderstorms were forecast to drop up to 20 mm (0.8 inch) of rain on Estevan and Weyburn in southeast Saskatchewan Monday, Environment Canada meteorologist Dale Marciski said.
Saskatchewan should see highs of 23 Celsius from Tuesday to Friday with a 40 to 60 percent chance of rain ranging from five to 10 mm (0.2 to 0.4 inch) each day, Marciski said.
"Manitoba is probably the driest of all the Prairie provinces and there's no rain forecast for today," he added.
Manitoba should see a high of 29 Celsius Tuesday, then 24 Celsius through to Friday with the Interlake region the only area likely to see perhaps up to five mm (0.2 inch) of rain.
Alberta should see highs of 21 to 25 to Friday with the most rain falling along the U.S. border at 10 mm Monday and 10 mm in the Peace River Valley Thursday and Friday.
